title: Werner-Seelenbinder-Halle
text:
Werner-Seelenbinder-Halle was an <a href="indoor%20arena">indoor sporting arena</a> located in the <a href="Prenzlauer%20Berg">Prenzlauer Berg</a> district of <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. It was named after the executed Berlin <a href="German%20resistance%20to%20Nazism">resistance</a> fighter <a href="Werner%20Seelenbinder">Werner Seelenbinder</a>, a German <a href="wrestling">wrestling</a> champion at several European championships and <a href="1936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a> athlete.
The arena opened in 1950 in what was then <a href="East%20Berlin">East Berlin</a>, in a converted hall that had been part of the central cattle market and slaughterhouse complex. It then hosted the first national meeting of the <a href="Free%20German%20Youth">Free German Youth</a>. One of the major sports venues in Berlin in the 20th century, the capacity of the arena was up to 10,000 people.
Until the opening of the <a href="Palace%20of%20the%20Republic%20%28Berlin%29">Palast der Republik</a> in 1976, East German mass organizations like the <a href="Socialist%20Unity%20Party%20of%20Germany">Socialist Unity Party of Germany</a> (SED) regularly used the Werner-Seelenbinder-Halle as a convention hall. From 1970 to 1990 it was also the site of the annual <a href="Festival%20of%20Political%20Songs">Festival of Political Songs</a>. On 7 March 1988 <a href="Depeche%20Mode">Depeche Mode</a> made their East German debut here, followed by <a href="The%20Wedding%20Present">The Wedding Present</a> and <a href="Jonathan%20Richman">Jonathan Richman</a> but also by <a href="Feeling%20B">Feeling B</a> and <a href="Rio%20Reiser">Rio Reiser</a> in the same year.
Werner-Seelenbinder-Halle was closed and demolished in 1993. It was replaced by the present-day <a href="Velodrom">Velodrom</a>.
